prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling a friend he is being creepy and pathetic following a breakup?
My friend was with this girl for about eight months. He is 22.

While he was with her, he would go on and on about how she was "the one" and how they were going to get married, etc. 

She recently broke up with him because he was moving way too fast in the relationship and he needs time to work on himself and deal with his anxiety.

He completely lost it after this. We ended up having to call 911 and have him taken to the hospital because he was calling her and us threatening harm on himself. 

He constantly calls her asking why she can't take him back, and he told us that if she's in the city, he might go to her place and "ask her in person". 

Well, me and my friends all took turns spending time with him after the hospital visit and on my turn I just lost it after hearing for the fifth time how he was going to "get her back."

I told him he was being creepy and pathetic and that she has made it abundantly clear that she doesn't want to get back together with him and he needs to stop all this behavior. 

He got really pissed and kicked me out of his apartment.

My friends told me that I probably could have done it in a nicer way but that they agree with me.

So AITA for telling him all that?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. Let me start by reading through the situation carefully.

The user's friend was in an 8-month relationship where he was really pushing for the future, saying things like "the one" and getting her to think about marriage. The girl broke up with him because he was moving too fast and he needs to work on himself and his anxiety. After the breakup, the guy starts acting out: threatening self-harm, calling 911, and then constantly trying to contact her, even threatening to go to her place. The user and friends took turns helping him, and when the user was with him, he kept talking about getting her back. The user snapped and told him he was being creepy and pathetic, leading to a fight and being kicked out. Friends said the user probably could have been nicer but agree with the message.

So, the question is whether the user is at fault here. The options are A (yes) or B (no). Let me break it down.

First, the friend's behavior after the breakup is clearly problematic. He's moving on to self-harm and stalking behavior. The user stepped in to tell him he's being creepy and pathetic, which is a direct confrontation. The user's friends agree with the content but think the approach could have been kinder. The user's actions were meant to stop the harmful behavior. The friend's actions are harmful and need to be addressed. The user's message was valid because the friend needed to stop his behavior. However, the way it was delivered might have been harsh, but the intent was good. Since the friends agree with the message, even if the delivery was rough, the user isn't necessarily wrong. The alternative is that the user had a right to confront the friend to prevent further harm. The friend's actions could be dangerous, so the user was trying to help. Therefore, the user isn't in the wrong. So answer B.
